div.p: My friendly willing service and all good things, well-learned, honorable, dear sir, etc.

As I discussed with you last time regarding my matter concerning Berger, I have done so, and therefore, if it is not convenient for you to write properly, do as you see necessary and good. But here is my request: If it cannot be more, at least help me to get back my money, which I lent to his son. Otherwise, it would be very difficult for me, and I would have to forgo much. He has never done anything for me for free in his life. However, I hope the arbitration process will also bring me something more. But whatever you do, I will be satisfied once, and let me know how I stand. And with this, I commend you to the one and good Lord God.
Given in Ill, on the Sunday before Valentine's Day in the year 1537.
Your willing servant, Hans Rudolf Lavater.
To the well-learned, honorable Master Heinrich Bullinger, preacher of the Zurich church, my especially trusted and dear sir, in his hand.
